availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

body.p: Pass through Cumberland Mountain, in the larger Appalachian Mountain range. Located at the state borders of Kentucky, Tennessee, and Virginia, the Cumberland Gap is one of three natural passes through the Appalachian Mountain range,and has been constantly used as trade and travel route during the 17th, 18th, and 19th centuries. During the Civil War, Union armies viewed the Cumberland Gap was viewed as an invasion route into Eastern Tennessee or Southwest Virginia, and changed hands several times throughout the conflict.

ab.bibl: Brian D. McKnight, Contested Borderland: The Civil War in Appalachian Kentucky and Tennessee (Lexington: The University Press of Kentucky).
